11.text: Get out of the way; turn off the road. Rid us of the Holy One of Israel!”

12.text: Therefore this is what the Holy One of Israel says: “Because you have rejected this message, trusting in oppression and relying on deceit,

13.text: this iniquity of yours is like a breach about to fail, a bulge in a high wall, whose collapse will come suddenly—in an instant!

14.text: It will break in pieces like a potter’s jar, shattered so that no fragment can be found. Not a shard will be found in the dust large enough to scoop the coals from a hearth or to skim the water from a cistern.”

15.text: For the Lord GOD, the Holy One of Israel, has said: “By repentance and rest you would be saved; your strength would lie in quiet confidence—but you were not willing.”

16.text: “No,” you say, “we will flee on horses.” Therefore you will flee! “We will ride swift horses,” but your pursuers will be faster.

17.text: A thousand will flee at the threat of one; at the threat of five you will all flee, until you are left alone like a pole on a mountaintop, like a banner on a hill.

18.text: Therefore the LORD longs to be gracious to you; therefore He rises to show you compassion, for the LORD is a just God. Blessed are all who wait for Him.

19.text: O people in Zion who dwell in Jerusalem, you will weep no more. He will surely be gracious when you cry for help; when He hears, He will answer you.

20.text: The Lord will give you the bread of adversity and the water of affliction, but your Teacher will no longer hide Himself—with your own eyes you will see Him.

21.text: And whether you turn to the right or to the left, your ears will hear this command behind you: “This is the way. Walk in it.”

22.text: So you will desecrate your silver-plated idols and your gold-plated images. You will throw them away like menstrual cloths, saying to them, “Be gone!”

23.text: Then He will send rain for the seed that you have sown in the ground, and the food that comes from your land will be rich and plentiful. On that day your cattle will graze in open pastures.

24.text: The oxen and donkeys that work the ground will eat salted fodder, winnowed with shovel and pitchfork.

25.text: And from every high mountain and every raised hill, streams of water will flow in the day of great slaughter, when the towers fall.

26.text: The light of the moon will be as bright as the sun, and the light of the sun will be seven times brighter—like the light of seven days—on the day that the LORD binds up the brokenness of His people and heals the wounds He has inflicted.

27.text: Behold, the Name of the LORD comes from afar, with burning anger and dense smoke. His lips are full of fury, and His tongue is like a consuming fire.

28.text: His breath is like a rushing torrent that rises to the neck. He comes to sift the nations in a sieve of destruction; He bridles the jaws of the peoples to lead them astray.

29.text: You will sing as on the night of a holy festival, and your heart will rejoice like one who walks to the music of a flute, going up to the mountain of the LORD, to the Rock of Israel.

30.text: And the LORD will cause His majestic voice to be heard and His mighty arm to be revealed, striking in angry wrath with a flame of consuming fire, and with cloudburst, storm, and hailstones.

31.text: For Assyria will be shattered at the voice of the LORD; He will strike them with His scepter.

32.text: And with every stroke of the rod of punishment that the LORD brings down on them, the tambourines and lyres will sound as He battles with weapons brandished.

33.text: For Topheth has long been prepared; it has been made ready for the king. Its funeral pyre is deep and wide, with plenty of fire and wood. The breath of the LORD, like a torrent of burning sulfur, sets it ablaze.

1.text: Woe to those who go down to Egypt for help, who rely on horses, who trust in their abundance of chariots and in their multitude of horsemen. They do not look to the Holy One of Israel; they do not seek the LORD.

2.text: Yet He too is wise and brings disaster; He does not call back His words. He will rise up against the house of the wicked and against the allies of evildoers.

3.text: But the Egyptians are men, not God; their horses are flesh, not spirit. When the LORD stretches out His hand, the helper will stumble, and the one he helps will fall; both will perish together.

4.text: For this is what the LORD has said to me: “Like a lion roaring or a young lion over its prey—and though a band of shepherds is called out against it, it is not terrified by their shouting or subdued by their clamor—so the LORD of Hosts will come down to do battle on Mount Zion and its heights.

5.text: Like birds hovering overhead, so the LORD of Hosts will protect Jerusalem. He will shield it and deliver it; He will pass over it and preserve it.”

6.text: Return to the One against whom you have so blatantly rebelled, O children of Israel.

7.text: For on that day, every one of you will reject the idols of silver and gold that your own hands have sinfully made.

8.text: “Then Assyria will fall, but not by the sword of man; a sword will devour them, but not one made by mortals. They will flee before the sword, and their young men will be put to forced labor.

9.text: Their rock will pass away for fear, and their princes will panic at the sight of the battle standard,” declares the LORD, whose fire is in Zion, whose furnace is in Jerusalem.

1.text: Behold, a king will reign in righteousness, and princes will rule with justice.

2.text: Each will be like a shelter from the wind, a refuge from the storm, like streams of water in a dry land, like the shadow of a great rock in an arid land.

3.text: Then the eyes of those who see will no longer be closed, and the ears of those who hear will listen.

4.text: The mind of the rash will know and understand, and the stammering tongue will speak clearly and fluently.

5.text: No longer will a fool be called noble, nor a scoundrel be respected.

6.text: For a fool speaks foolishness; his mind plots iniquity. He practices ungodliness and speaks falsely about the LORD; he leaves the hungry empty and deprives the thirsty of drink.

7.text: The weapons of the scoundrel are destructive; he hatches plots to destroy the poor with lies, even when the plea of the needy is just.

8.text: But a noble man makes honorable plans; he stands up for worthy causes.

9.text: Stand up, you complacent women; listen to me. Give ear to my word, you overconfident daughters.

10.text: In a little more than a year you will tremble, O secure ones. For the grape harvest will fail and the fruit harvest will not arrive.

11.text: Shudder, you ladies of leisure; tremble, you daughters of complacency. Strip yourselves bare and put sackcloth around your waists.

12.text: Beat your breasts for the pleasant fields, for the fruitful vines,

13.text: and for the land of my people, overgrown with thorns and briers—even for every house of merriment in this city of revelry.

14.text: For the palace will be forsaken, the busy city abandoned. The hill and the watchtower will become caves forever—the delight of wild donkeys and a pasture for flocks—

15.text: until the Spirit is poured out upon us from on high. Then the desert will be an orchard, and the orchard will seem like a forest.

16.text: Then justice will inhabit the wilderness, and righteousness will dwell in the fertile field.

17.text: The work of righteousness will be peace; the service of righteousness will be quiet confidence forever.

18.text: Then my people will dwell in a peaceful place, in safe and secure places of rest.

19.text: But hail will level the forest, and the city will sink to the depths.

20.text: Blessed are those who sow beside abundant waters, who let the ox and donkey range freely.

1.text: Woe to you, O destroyer never destroyed, O traitor never betrayed! When you have finished destroying, you will be destroyed. When you have finished betraying, you will be betrayed.

2.text: O LORD, be gracious to us! We wait for You. Be our strength every morning and our salvation in time of trouble.

3.text: The peoples flee the thunder of Your voice; the nations scatter when You rise.

4.text: Your spoil, O nations, is gathered as by locusts; like a swarm of locusts men sweep over it.

5.text: The LORD is exalted, for He dwells on high; He has filled Zion with justice and righteousness.

6.text: He will be the sure foundation for your times, a storehouse of salvation, wisdom, and knowledge. The fear of the LORD is Zion’s treasure.

7.text: Behold, their valiant ones cry aloud in the streets; the envoys of peace weep bitterly.

8.text: The highways are deserted; travel has ceased. The treaty has been broken, the witnesses are despised, and human life is disregarded.

9.text: The land mourns and languishes; Lebanon is ashamed and decayed. Sharon is like a desert; Bashan and Carmel shake off their leaves.

10.text: “Now I will arise,” says the LORD. “Now I will lift Myself up. Now I will be exalted.

11.text: You conceive chaff; you give birth to stubble. Your breath is a fire that will consume you.

12.text: The peoples will be burned to ashes, like thorns cut down and set ablaze.

13.text: You who are far off, hear what I have done; you who are near, acknowledge My might.”

14.text: The sinners in Zion are afraid; trembling grips the ungodly: “Who of us can dwell with a consuming fire? Who of us can dwell with everlasting flames?”

15.text: He who walks righteously and speaks with sincerity, who refuses gain from extortion, whose hand never takes a bribe, who stops his ears against murderous plots and shuts his eyes tightly against evil—

16.text: he will dwell on the heights; the mountain fortress will be his refuge; his food will be provided and his water assured.

17.text: Your eyes will see the King in His beauty and behold a land that stretches afar.

18.text: Your mind will ponder the former terror: “Where is he who tallies? Where is he who weighs? Where is he who counts the towers?”

19.text: You will no longer see the insolent, a people whose speech is unintelligible, who stammer in a language you cannot understand.

20.text: Look upon Zion, the city of our appointed feasts. Your eyes will see Jerusalem, a peaceful pasture, a tent that does not wander; its tent pegs will not be pulled up, nor will any of its cords be broken.

21.text: But there the Majestic One, our LORD, will be for us a place of rivers and wide canals, where no galley with oars will row, and no majestic vessel will pass.

22.text: For the LORD is our Judge, the LORD is our lawgiver, the LORD is our King. It is He who will save us.

23.text: Your ropes are slack; they cannot secure the mast or spread the sail. Then an abundance of spoils will be divided, and even the lame will carry off plunder.

24.text: And no resident of Zion will say, “I am sick.” The people who dwell there will be forgiven of iniquity.

1.text: Come near, O nations, to listen; pay attention, O peoples. Let the earth hear, and all that fills it, the world and all that springs from it.

2.text: The LORD is angry with all the nations and furious with all their armies. He will devote them to destruction; He will give them over to slaughter.

3.text: Their slain will be left unburied, and the stench of their corpses will rise; the mountains will flow with their blood.

4.text: All the stars of heaven will be dissolved. The skies will be rolled up like a scroll, and all their stars will fall like withered leaves from the vine, like foliage from the fig tree.

5.text: When My sword has drunk its fill in the heavens, then it will come down upon Edom, upon the people I have devoted to destruction.

6.text: The sword of the LORD is bathed in blood. It drips with fat—with the blood of lambs and goats, with the fat of the kidneys of rams. For the LORD has a sacrifice in Bozrah, a great slaughter in the land of Edom.

7.text: And the wild oxen will fall with them, the young bulls with the strong ones. Their land will be drenched with blood, and their soil will be soaked with fat.

8.text: For the LORD has a day of vengeance, a year of recompense for the cause of Zion.

9.text: Edom’s streams will be turned to tar, and her soil to sulfur; her land will become a blazing pitch.

10.text: It will not be quenched—day or night. Its smoke will ascend forever. From generation to generation it will lie desolate; no one will ever again pass through it.

11.text: The desert owl and screech owl will possess it, and the great owl and raven will dwell in it. The LORD will stretch out over Edom a measuring line of chaos and a plumb line of destruction.

12.text: No nobles will be left to proclaim a king, and all her princes will come to nothing.

13.text: Her towers will be overgrown with thorns, her fortresses with thistles and briers. She will become a haunt for jackals, an abode for ostriches.

14.text: The desert creatures will meet with hyenas, and one wild goat will call to another. There the night creature will settle and find her place of repose.

15.text: There the owl will make her nest; she will lay and hatch her eggs and gather her brood under her shadow. Even there the birds of prey will gather, each with its mate.

16.text: Search and read the scroll of the LORD: Not one of these will go missing, not one will lack her mate, because He has ordered it by His mouth, and He will gather them by His Spirit.

17.text: He has allotted their portion; His hand has distributed it by measure. They will possess it forever; they will dwell in it from generation to generation.

1.text: The wilderness and the dry land will be glad; the desert will rejoice and blossom like a rose.

2.text: It will bloom profusely and rejoice with joy and singing. The glory of Lebanon will be given to it, the splendor of Carmel and Sharon. They will see the glory of the LORD, the splendor of our God.

3.text: Strengthen the limp hands and steady the feeble knees!

4.text: Say to those with anxious hearts: “Be strong, do not fear! Behold, your God will come with vengeance. With divine retribution He will come to save you.”

5.text: Then the eyes of the blind will be opened and the ears of the deaf unstopped.

6.text: Then the lame will leap like a deer and the mute tongue will shout for joy. For waters will gush forth in the wilderness, and streams in the desert.

7.text: The parched ground will become a pool, the thirsty land springs of water. In the haunt where jackals once lay, there will be grass and reeds and papyrus.

8.text: And there will be a highway called the Way of Holiness. The unclean will not travel it—only those who walk in the Way—and fools will not stray onto it.

9.text: No lion will be there, and no vicious beast will go up on it. Such will not be found there, but the redeemed will walk upon it.

10.text: So the redeemed of the LORD will return and enter Zion with singing, crowned with everlasting joy. Gladness and joy will overtake them, and sorrow and sighing will flee.

1.text: In the fourteenth year of Hezekiah’s reign, Sennacherib king of Assyria attacked and captured all the fortified cities of Judah.

2.text: And the king of Assyria sent the Rabshakeh, with a great army, from Lachish to King Hezekiah at Jerusalem. And he stopped by the aqueduct of the upper pool, on the road to the Launderer’s Field.

3.text: Then Eliakim son of Hilkiah the palace administrator, Shebna the scribe, and Joah son of Asaph the recorder, went out to him.

4.text: The Rabshakeh said to them, “Tell Hezekiah that this is what the great king, the king of Assyria, says: What is the basis of this confidence of yours?

5.text: You claim to have a strategy and strength for war, but these are empty words. In whom are you now trusting, that you have rebelled against me?

6.text: Look now, you are trusting in Egypt, that splintered reed of a staff that will pierce the hand of anyone who leans on it. Such is Pharaoh king of Egypt to all who trust in him.

7.text: But if you say to me, ‘We trust in the LORD our God,’ is He not the One whose high places and altars Hezekiah has removed, saying to Judah and Jerusalem, ‘You must worship before this altar’?

8.text: Now, therefore, make a bargain with my master, the king of Assyria. I will give you two thousand horses—if you can put riders on them!

9.text: For how can you repel a single officer among the least of my master’s servants when you depend on Egypt for chariots and horsemen?

10.text: So now, was it apart from the LORD that I have come up against this land to destroy it? The LORD Himself said to me, ‘Go up against this land and destroy it.’”

11.text: Then Eliakim, Shebna, and Joah said to the Rabshakeh, “Please speak to your servants in Aramaic, since we understand it. Do not speak to us in Hebrew in the hearing of the people on the wall.”

12.text: But the Rabshakeh replied, “Has my master sent me to speak these words only to you and your master, and not to the men sitting on the wall, who are destined with you to eat their own dung and drink their own urine?”

13.text: Then the Rabshakeh stood and called out loudly in Hebrew: “Hear the words of the great king, the king of Assyria!

14.text: This is what the king says: Do not let Hezekiah deceive you, for he cannot deliver you.

15.text: Do not let Hezekiah persuade you to trust in the LORD when he says, ‘The LORD will surely deliver us; this city will not be given into the hand of the king of Assyria.’

16.text: Do not listen to Hezekiah, for this is what the king of Assyria says: Make peace with me and come out to me. Then every one of you will eat from his own vine and his own fig tree, and drink water from his own cistern,

17.text: until I come and take you away to a land like your own—a land of grain and new wine, a land of bread and vineyards.

18.text: Do not let Hezekiah mislead you when he says, ‘The LORD will deliver us.’ Has the god of any nation ever delivered his land from the hand of the king of Assyria?

19.text: Where are the gods of Hamath and Arpad? Where are the gods of Sepharvaim? Have they delivered Samaria from my hand?

20.text: Who among all the gods of these lands has delivered his land from my hand? How then can the LORD deliver Jerusalem from my hand?”

21.text: But the people remained silent and did not answer a word, for Hezekiah had commanded, “Do not answer him.”

22.text: Then Hilkiah’s son Eliakim the palace administrator, Shebna the scribe, and Asaph’s son Joah the recorder came to Hezekiah with their clothes torn, and they relayed to him the words of the Rabshakeh.

1.text: On hearing this report, King Hezekiah tore his clothes, put on sackcloth, and entered the house of the LORD.

2.text: And he sent Eliakim the palace administrator, Shebna the scribe, and the leading priests, all wearing sackcloth, to the prophet Isaiah son of Amoz

3.text: to tell him, “This is what Hezekiah says: Today is a day of distress, rebuke, and disgrace; for children have come to the point of birth, but there is no strength to deliver them.

4.text: Perhaps the LORD your God will hear the words of the Rabshakeh, whom his master the king of Assyria has sent to defy the living God, and He will rebuke him for the words that the LORD your God has heard. Therefore lift up a prayer for the remnant that still survives.”

5.text: So the servants of King Hezekiah went to Isaiah,

6.text: who replied, “Tell your master that this is what the LORD says: ‘Do not be afraid of the words you have heard, with which the servants of the king of Assyria have blasphemed Me.

7.text: Behold, I will put a spirit in him so that he will hear a rumor and return to his own land, where I will cause him to fall by the sword.’”

8.text: When the Rabshakeh heard that the king of Assyria had left Lachish, he withdrew and found the king fighting against Libnah.

9.text: Now Sennacherib had been warned about Tirhakah king of Cush: “He has set out to fight against you.” On hearing this, Sennacherib sent messengers to Hezekiah, saying,

10.text: “Give this message to Hezekiah king of Judah: ‘Do not let your God, in whom you trust, deceive you by saying that Jerusalem will not be delivered into the hand of the king of Assyria.

11.text: Surely you have heard what the kings of Assyria have done to all the other countries, devoting them to destruction. Will you then be spared?

12.text: Did the gods of the nations destroyed by my fathers rescue those nations—the gods of Gozan, Haran, and Rezeph, and of the people of Eden in Telassar?

13.text: Where are the kings of Hamath, Arpad, Sepharvaim, Hena, and Ivvah?’”

14.text: So Hezekiah received the letter from the messengers, read it, and went up to the house of the LORD and spread it out before the LORD.

15.text: And Hezekiah prayed to the LORD:

16.text: “O LORD of Hosts, God of Israel, enthroned above the cherubim, You alone are God over all the kingdoms of the earth. You made the heavens and the earth.

17.text: Incline Your ear, O LORD, and hear; open Your eyes, O LORD, and see. Listen to all the words that Sennacherib has sent to defy the living God.

18.text: Truly, O LORD, the kings of Assyria have laid waste all these countries and their lands.

19.text: They have cast their gods into the fire and destroyed them, for they were not gods, but only wood and stone—the work of human hands.

20.text: And now, O LORD our God, save us from his hand, so that all the kingdoms of the earth may know that You alone, O LORD, are God.”

21.text: Then Isaiah son of Amoz sent a message to Hezekiah: “This is what the LORD, the God of Israel, says: Because you have prayed to Me concerning Sennacherib king of Assyria,

22.text: this is the word that the LORD has spoken against him: ‘The Virgin Daughter of Zion despises you and mocks you; the Daughter of Jerusalem shakes her head behind you.

23.text: Whom have you taunted and blasphemed? Against whom have you raised your voice and lifted your eyes in pride? Against the Holy One of Israel!

24.text: Through your servants you have taunted the Lord, and you have said: “With my many chariots I have ascended to the heights of the mountains, to the remote peaks of Lebanon. I have cut down its tallest cedars, the finest of its cypresses. I have reached its farthest heights, the densest of its forests.

25.text: I have dug wells and drunk foreign waters. With the soles of my feet I have dried up all the streams of Egypt.”

26.text: Have you not heard? Long ago I ordained it; in days of old I planned it. Now I have brought it to pass, that you should crush fortified cities into piles of rubble.

27.text: Therefore their inhabitants, devoid of power, are dismayed and ashamed. They are like plants in the field, tender green shoots, grass on the rooftops, scorched before it is grown.

28.text: But I know your sitting down, your going out and coming in, and your raging against Me.

29.text: Because your rage and arrogance against Me have reached My ears, I will put My hook in your nose and My bit in your mouth; I will send you back the way you came.’

30.text: And this will be a sign to you, O Hezekiah: This year you will eat what grows on its own, and in the second year what springs from the same. But in the third year you will sow and reap; you will plant vineyards and eat their fruit.

31.text: And the surviving remnant of the house of Judah will again take root below and bear fruit above.

32.text: For a remnant will go forth from Jerusalem, and survivors from Mount Zion. The zeal of the LORD of Hosts will accomplish this.

33.text: So this is what the LORD says about the king of Assyria: ‘He will not enter this city or shoot an arrow into it. He will not come before it with a shield or build up a siege ramp against it.

34.text: He will go back the way he came, and he will not enter this city,’ declares the LORD.

35.text: ‘I will defend this city and save it for My own sake and for the sake of My servant David.’”

36.text: Then the angel of the LORD went out and struck down 185,000 men in the camp of the Assyrians. When the people got up the next morning, there were all the dead bodies!

37.text: So Sennacherib king of Assyria broke camp and withdrew. He returned to Nineveh and stayed there.

38.text: One day, while he was worshiping in the temple of his god Nisroch, his sons Adrammelech and Sharezer put him to the sword and escaped to the land of Ararat. And his son Esar-haddon reigned in his place.

1.text: In those days Hezekiah became mortally ill. The prophet Isaiah son of Amoz came to him and said, “This is what the LORD says: ‘Put your house in order, for you are about to die; you will not recover.’”

2.text: Then Hezekiah turned his face to the wall and prayed to the LORD,

3.text: saying, “Please, O LORD, remember how I have walked before You faithfully and with wholehearted devotion; I have done what is good in Your sight.” And Hezekiah wept bitterly.

4.text: And the word of the LORD came to Isaiah, saying,

5.text: “Go and tell Hezekiah that this is what the LORD, the God of your father David, says: ‘I have heard your prayer; I have seen your tears. Behold, I will add fifteen years to your life.

6.text: And I will deliver you and this city from the hand of the king of Assyria. I will defend this city.

7.text: This will be a sign to you from the LORD that He will do what He has promised:

8.text: I will make the sun’s shadow that falls on the stairway of Ahaz go back ten steps.’” So the sunlight went back the ten steps it had descended.

9.text: This is a writing by Hezekiah king of Judah after his illness and recovery:

10.text: I said, “In the prime of my life I must go through the gates of Sheol and be deprived of the remainder of my years.”

11.text: I said, “I will never again see the LORD, even the LORD, in the land of the living; I will no longer look on mankind with those who dwell in this world.

12.text: My dwelling has been picked up and removed from me like a shepherd’s tent. I have rolled up my life like a weaver; He cuts me off from the loom; from day until night You make an end of me.

13.text: I composed myself until the morning. Like a lion He breaks all my bones; from day until night You make an end of me.

14.text: I chirp like a swallow or crane; I moan like a dove. My eyes grow weak as I look upward. O Lord, I am oppressed; be my security.”

15.text: What can I say? He has spoken to me, and He Himself has done this. I will walk slowly all my years because of the anguish of my soul.

16.text: O Lord, by such things men live, and in all of them my spirit finds life. You have restored me to health and have let me live.

17.text: Surely for my own welfare I had such great anguish; but Your love has delivered me from the pit of oblivion, for You have cast all my sins behind Your back.

18.text: For Sheol cannot thank You; Death cannot praise You. Those who descend to the Pit cannot hope for Your faithfulness.

19.text: The living, only the living, can thank You, as I do today; fathers will tell their children about Your faithfulness.

20.text: The LORD will save me; we will play songs on stringed instruments all the days of our lives in the house of the LORD.

21.text: Now Isaiah had said, “Prepare a lump of pressed figs and apply it to the boil, and he will recover.”

22.text: And Hezekiah had asked, “What will be the sign that I will go up to the house of the LORD?”

1.text: At that time Merodach-baladan son of Baladan king of Babylon sent letters and a gift to Hezekiah, for he had heard about Hezekiah’s illness and recovery.

2.text: And Hezekiah welcomed the envoys gladly and showed them what was in his treasure house—the silver, the gold, the spices, and the precious oil, as well as his entire armory—all that was found in his storehouses. There was nothing in his palace or in all his dominion that Hezekiah did not show them.

3.text: Then the prophet Isaiah went to King Hezekiah and asked, “Where did those men come from, and what did they say to you?” “They came to me from a distant land,” Hezekiah replied, “from Babylon.”

4.text: “What have they seen in your palace?” Isaiah asked. “They have seen everything in my palace,” answered Hezekiah. “There is nothing among my treasures that I did not show them.”

5.text: Then Isaiah said to Hezekiah, “Hear the word of the LORD of Hosts:

6.text: The time will surely come when everything in your palace and all that your fathers have stored up until this day will be carried off to Babylon. Nothing will be left, says the LORD.

7.text: And some of your descendants, your own flesh and blood, will be taken away to be eunuchs in the palace of the king of Babylon.”

8.text: But Hezekiah said to Isaiah, “The word of the LORD that you have spoken is good.” For he thought, “At least there will be peace and security in my lifetime.”

1.text: “Comfort, comfort My people,” says your God.

2.text: “Speak tenderly to Jerusalem, and proclaim to her that her forced labor has been completed; her iniquity has been pardoned. For she has received from the hand of the LORD double for all her sins.”

3.text: A voice of one calling: “Prepare the way for the LORD in the wilderness; make a straight highway for our God in the desert.

4.text: Every valley shall be lifted up, and every mountain and hill made low; the uneven ground will become smooth, and the rugged land a plain.

5.text: And the glory of the LORD will be revealed, and all humanity together will see it.” For the mouth of the LORD has spoken.

6.text: A voice says, “Cry out!” And I asked, “What should I cry out?” “All flesh is like grass, and all its glory like the flowers of the field.

7.text: The grass withers and the flowers fall when the breath of the LORD blows on them; indeed, the people are grass.

8.text: The grass withers and the flowers fall, but the word of our God stands forever.”

9.text: Go up on a high mountain, O Zion, herald of good news. Raise your voice loudly, O Jerusalem, herald of good news. Lift it up, do not be afraid! Say to the cities of Judah, “Here is your God!”

10.text: Behold, the Lord GOD comes with might, and His arm establishes His rule. His reward is with Him, and His recompense accompanies Him.

11.text: He tends His flock like a shepherd; He gathers the lambs in His arms and carries them close to His heart. He gently leads the nursing ewes.

12.text: Who has measured the waters in the hollow of his hand, or marked off the heavens with the span of his hand? Who has held the dust of the earth in a basket, or weighed the mountains on a scale and the hills with a balance?

13.text: Who has directed the Spirit of the LORD, or informed Him as His counselor?

14.text: Whom did He consult to enlighten Him, and who taught Him the paths of justice? Who imparted knowledge to Him and showed Him the way of understanding?

15.text: Surely the nations are like a drop in a bucket; they are considered a speck of dust on the scales; He lifts up the islands like fine dust.

16.text: Lebanon is not sufficient for fuel, nor its animals enough for a burnt offering.

17.text: All the nations are as nothing before Him; He regards them as nothingness and emptiness.

18.text: To whom will you liken God? To what image will you compare Him?

19.text: To an idol that a craftsman casts and a metalworker overlays with gold and fits with silver chains?

20.text: One lacking such an offering chooses wood that will not rot. He seeks a skilled craftsman to set up an idol that will not topple.

21.text: Do you not know? Have you not heard? Has it not been declared to you from the beginning? Have you not understood since the foundation of the earth?

22.text: He sits enthroned above the circle of the earth; its dwellers are like grasshoppers. He stretches out the heavens like a curtain, and spreads them out like a tent to dwell in.

23.text: He brings the princes to nothing and makes the rulers of the earth meaningless.

24.text: No sooner are they planted, no sooner are they sown, no sooner have their stems taken root in the ground, than He blows on them and they wither, and a whirlwind sweeps them away like stubble.

25.text: “To whom will you liken Me, or who is My equal?” asks the Holy One.

26.text: Lift up your eyes on high: Who created all these? He leads forth the starry host by number; He calls each one by name. Because of His great power and mighty strength, not one of them is missing.

27.text: Why do you say, O Jacob, and why do you assert, O Israel, “My way is hidden from the LORD, and my claim is ignored by my God”?

28.text: Do you not know? Have you not heard? The LORD is the everlasting God, the Creator of the ends of the earth. He will not grow tired or weary; His understanding is beyond searching out.

29.text: He gives power to the faint and increases the strength of the weak.

30.text: Even youths grow tired and weary, and young men stumble and fall.

31.text: But those who wait upon the LORD will renew their strength; they will mount up with wings like eagles; they will run and not grow weary, they will walk and not faint.

1.text: “Be silent before Me, O islands, and let the peoples renew their strength. Let them come forward and testify; let us together draw near for judgment.

2.text: Who has aroused one from the east and called him to his feet in righteousness? He hands nations over to him and subdues kings before him. He turns them to dust with his sword, to windblown chaff with his bow.

3.text: He pursues them, going on safely, hardly touching the path with his feet.

4.text: Who has performed this and carried it out, calling forth the generations from the beginning? I, the LORD—the first and the last—I am He.”

5.text: The islands see and fear; the ends of the earth tremble. They approach and come forward.

6.text: Each one helps the other and says to his brother, “Be strong!”

7.text: The craftsman encourages the goldsmith, and he who wields the hammer cheers him who strikes the anvil, saying of the welding, “It is good.” He nails it down so it will not be toppled.

8.text: “But you, O Israel, My servant, Jacob, whom I have chosen, descendant of Abraham My friend—

9.text: I brought you from the ends of the earth and called you from its farthest corners. I said, ‘You are My servant.’ I have chosen and not rejected you.

10.text: Do not fear, for I am with you; do not be afraid, for I am your God. I will strengthen you; I will surely help you; I will uphold you with My righteous right hand.

11.text: Behold, all who rage against you will be ashamed and disgraced; those who contend with you will be reduced to nothing and will perish.

12.text: You will seek them but will not find them. Those who wage war against you will come to nothing.

13.text: For I am the LORD your God, who takes hold of your right hand and tells you: Do not fear, I will help you.

14.text: Do not fear, O Jacob, you worm, O few men of Israel. I will help you,” declares the LORD. “Your Redeemer is the Holy One of Israel.

15.text: Behold, I will make you into a threshing sledge, new and sharp, with many teeth. You will thresh the mountains and crush them, and reduce the hills to chaff.

16.text: You will winnow them, and a wind will carry them away; a gale will scatter them. But you will rejoice in the LORD; you will glory in the Holy One of Israel.

17.text: The poor and needy seek water, but there is none; their tongues are parched with thirst. I, the LORD, will answer them; I, the God of Israel, will not forsake them.

18.text: I will open rivers on the barren heights, and fountains in the middle of the valleys. I will turn the desert into a pool of water, and the dry land into flowing springs.

19.text: I will plant cedars in the wilderness, acacias, myrtles, and olive trees. I will set cypresses in the desert, elms and boxwood together,

20.text: so that all may see and know, may consider and understand, that the hand of the LORD has done this and the Holy One of Israel has created it.”

21.text: “Present your case,” says the LORD. “Submit your arguments,” says the King of Jacob.

22.text: “Let them come and tell us what will happen. Tell the former things, so that we may reflect on them and know the outcome. Or announce to us what is coming.

23.text: Tell us the things that are to come, so that we may know that you are gods. Yes, do something good or evil, that we may look on together in dismay.

24.text: Behold, you are nothing and your work is of no value. Anyone who chooses you is detestable.

25.text: I have raised up one from the north, and he has come—one from the east who calls on My name. He will march over rulers as if they were mortar, like a potter who treads the clay.

26.text: Who has declared this from the beginning, so that we may know, and from times past, so that we may say: ‘He was right’? No one announced it, no one foretold it, no one heard your words.

27.text: I was the first to tell Zion: ‘Look, here they are!’ And I gave to Jerusalem a herald of good news.

28.text: When I look, there is no one; there is no counselor among them; when I ask them, they have nothing to say.

29.text: See, they are all a delusion; their works amount to nothing; their images are as empty as the wind.

1.text: “Here is My Servant, whom I uphold, My Chosen One, in whom My soul delights. I will put My Spirit on Him, and He will bring justice to the nations.

2.text: He will not cry out or raise His voice, nor make His voice heard in the streets.

3.text: A bruised reed He will not break and a smoldering wick He will not extinguish; He will faithfully bring forth justice.

4.text: He will not grow weak or discouraged before He has established justice on the earth. In His law the islands will put their hope.”

5.text: This is what God the LORD says—He who created the heavens and stretched them out, who spread out the earth and its offspring, who gives breath to the people on it and life to those who walk in it:

6.text: “I, the LORD, have called you for a righteous purpose, and I will take hold of your hand. I will keep you and appoint you to be a covenant for the people and a light to the nations,

7.text: to open the eyes of the blind, to bring prisoners out of the dungeon and those sitting in darkness out from the prison house.

8.text: I am the LORD; that is My name! I will not yield My glory to another or My praise to idols.

9.text: Behold, the former things have happened, and now I declare new things. Before they spring forth I proclaim them to you.”

10.text: Sing to the LORD a new song—His praise from the ends of the earth—you who go down to the sea, and all that is in it, you islands, and all who dwell in them.

11.text: Let the desert and its cities raise their voices; let the villages of Kedar cry aloud. Let the people of Sela sing for joy; let them cry out from the mountaintops.

12.text: Let them give glory to the LORD and declare His praise in the islands.

13.text: The LORD goes forth like a mighty one; He stirs up His zeal like a warrior. He shouts; yes, He roars in triumph over His enemies:

14.text: “I have kept silent from ages past; I have remained quiet and restrained. But now I will groan like a woman in labor; I will at once gasp and pant.

15.text: I will lay waste the mountains and hills and dry up all their vegetation. I will turn the rivers into dry land and drain the marshes.

16.text: I will lead the blind by a way they did not know; I will guide them on unfamiliar paths. I will turn darkness into light before them and rough places into level ground. These things I will do for them, and I will not forsake them.

17.text: But those who trust in idols and say to molten images, ‘You are our gods!’ will be turned back in utter shame.

18.text: Listen, you deaf ones; look, you blind ones, that you may see!

19.text: Who is blind but My servant, or deaf like the messenger I am sending? Who is blind like My covenant partner, or blind like the servant of the LORD?

20.text: Though seeing many things, you do not keep watch. Though your ears are open, you do not hear.”

21.text: The LORD was pleased, for the sake of His righteousness, to magnify His law and make it glorious.

22.text: But this is a people plundered and looted, all trapped in caves or imprisoned in dungeons. They have become plunder with no one to rescue them, and loot with no one to say, “Send them back!”

23.text: Who among you will pay attention to this? Who will listen and obey hereafter?

24.text: Who gave Jacob up for spoil, and Israel to the plunderers? Was it not the LORD, against whom we have sinned? They were unwilling to walk in His ways, and they would not obey His law.

25.text: So He poured out on them His furious anger and the fierceness of battle. It enveloped them in flames, but they did not understand; it consumed them, but they did not take it to heart.

1.text: But now, this is what the LORD says—He who created you, O Jacob, and He who formed you, O Israel: “Do not fear, for I have redeemed you; I have called you by your name; you are Mine!

2.text: When you pass through the waters, I will be with you; and when you go through the rivers, they will not overwhelm you. When you walk through the fire, you will not be scorched; the flames will not set you ablaze.

3.text: For I am the LORD your God, the Holy One of Israel, your Savior; I give Egypt for your ransom, Cush and Seba in your place.

4.text: Because you are precious and honored in My sight, and because I love you, I will give men in exchange for you and nations in place of your life.

5.text: Do not be afraid, for I am with you; I will bring your offspring from the east and gather you from the west.

6.text: I will say to the north, ‘Give them up!’ and to the south, ‘Do not hold them back!’ Bring My sons from afar, and My daughters from the ends of the earth—

7.text: everyone called by My name and created for My glory, whom I have indeed formed and made.”

8.text: Bring out a people who have eyes but are blind, and who have ears but are deaf.

9.text: All the nations gather together and the peoples assemble. Who among them can declare this, and proclaim to us the former things? Let them present their witnesses to vindicate them, so that others may hear and say, “It is true.”

10.text: “You are My witnesses,” declares the LORD, “and My servant whom I have chosen, so that you may consider and believe Me and understand that I am He. Before Me no god was formed, and after Me none will come.

11.text: I, yes I, am the LORD, and there is no Savior but Me.

12.text: I alone decreed and saved and proclaimed—I, and not some foreign god among you. So you are My witnesses,” declares the LORD, “that I am God.

13.text: Even from eternity I am He, and none can deliver out of My hand. When I act, who can reverse it?”

14.text: Thus says the LORD your Redeemer, the Holy One of Israel: “For your sake, I will send to Babylon and bring them all as fugitives, even the Chaldeans, in the ships in which they rejoice.

15.text: I am the LORD, your Holy One, the Creator of Israel, and your King.”

16.text: Thus says the LORD, who makes a way in the sea and a path through the surging waters,

17.text: who brings out the chariots and horses, the armies and warriors together, to lie down, never to rise again; to be extinguished, snuffed out like a wick:

18.text: “Do not call to mind the former things; pay no attention to the things of old.

19.text: Behold, I am about to do something new; even now it is coming. Do you not see it? Indeed, I will make a way in the wilderness and streams in the desert.

20.text: The beasts of the field will honor Me, the jackals and the ostriches, because I provide water in the wilderness and rivers in the desert, to give drink to My chosen people.

21.text: The people I formed for Myself will declare My praise.

22.text: But you have not called on Me, O Jacob, because you have grown weary of Me, O Israel.

23.text: You have not brought Me sheep for burnt offerings, nor honored Me with your sacrifices. I have not burdened you with offerings, nor wearied you with frankincense.

24.text: You have not bought Me sweet cane with your silver, nor satisfied Me with the fat of your sacrifices. But you have burdened Me with your sins; you have wearied Me with your iniquities.

25.text: I, yes I, am He who blots out your transgressions for My own sake and remembers your sins no more.

26.text: Remind Me, let us argue the matter together. State your case, so that you may be vindicated.

27.text: Your first father sinned, and your spokesmen rebelled against Me.

28.text: So I will disgrace the princes of your sanctuary, and I will devote Jacob to destruction and Israel to reproach.”

1.text: But now listen, O Jacob My servant, Israel, whom I have chosen.

2.text: This is the word of the LORD, your Maker, who formed you from the womb and who will help you: “Do not be afraid, O Jacob My servant, Jeshurun, whom I have chosen.

3.text: For I will pour water on the thirsty land, and currents on the dry ground. I will pour out My Spirit on your descendants, and My blessing on your offspring.

4.text: They will sprout among the grass like willows by flowing streams.

5.text: One will say, ‘I belong to the LORD,’ another will call himself by the name of Jacob, and still another will write on his hand, ‘The LORD’s,’ and will take the name of Israel.”

6.text: Thus says the LORD, the King and Redeemer of Israel, the LORD of Hosts: “I am the first and I am the last, and there is no God but Me.

7.text: Who then is like Me? Let him say so! Let him declare his case before Me, since I established an ancient people. Let him foretell the things to come, and what is to take place.

8.text: Do not tremble or fear. Have I not told you and declared it long ago? You are My witnesses! Is there any God but Me? There is no other Rock; I know not one.”

9.text: All makers of idols are nothing, and the things they treasure are worthless. Their witnesses fail to see or comprehend, so they are put to shame.

10.text: Who fashions a god or casts an idol which profits him nothing?

11.text: Behold, all his companions will be put to shame, for the craftsmen themselves are only human. Let them all assemble and take their stand; they will all be brought to terror and shame.

12.text: The blacksmith takes a tool and labors over the coals; he fashions an idol with hammers and forges it with his strong arms. Yet he grows hungry and loses his strength; he fails to drink water and grows faint.

13.text: The woodworker extends a measuring line; he marks it out with a stylus; he shapes it with chisels and outlines it with a compass. He fashions it in the likeness of man, like man in all his glory, that it may dwell in a shrine.

14.text: He cuts down cedars or retrieves a cypress or oak. He lets it grow strong among the trees of the forest. He plants a laurel, and the rain makes it grow.

15.text: It serves as fuel for man. He takes some of it to warm himself, and he kindles a fire and bakes his bread. He also fashions it into a god and worships it; he makes an idol and bows down to it.

16.text: He burns half of it in the fire, and he roasts meat on that half. He eats the roast and is satisfied. Indeed, he warms himself and says, “Ah! I am warm; I see the fire.”

17.text: From the rest he makes a god, his graven image. He bows down to it and worships; he prays to it and says, “Save me, for you are my god.”

18.text: They do not comprehend or discern, for He has shut their eyes so they cannot see and closed their minds so they cannot understand.

19.text: And no one considers in his heart, no one has the knowledge or insight to say, “I burned half of it in the fire, and I baked bread on its coals; I roasted meat and I ate. Shall I make something detestable with the rest of it? Shall I bow down to a block of wood?”

20.text: He feeds on ashes. His deluded heart has led him astray, and he cannot deliver himself or say, “Is not this thing in my right hand a lie?”

21.text: Remember these things, O Jacob, for you are My servant, O Israel. I have made you, and you are My servant; O Israel, I will never forget you.

22.text: I have blotted out your transgressions like a cloud, and your sins like a mist. Return to Me, for I have redeemed you.

23.text: Sing for joy, O heavens, for the LORD has done this; shout aloud, O depths of the earth. Break forth in song, O mountains, you forests and all your trees. For the LORD has redeemed Jacob, and revealed His glory in Israel.

24.text: Thus says the LORD, your Redeemer who formed you from the womb: “I am the LORD, who has made all things, who alone stretched out the heavens, who by Myself spread out the earth,

25.text: who foils the signs of false prophets and makes fools of diviners, who confounds the wise and turns their knowledge into nonsense,

26.text: who confirms the message of His servant and fulfills the counsel of His messengers, who says of Jerusalem, ‘She will be inhabited,’ and of the cities of Judah, ‘They will be rebuilt, and I will restore their ruins,’

27.text: who says to the depths of the sea, ‘Be dry, and I will dry up your currents,’

28.text: who says of Cyrus, ‘My shepherd will fulfill all that I desire,’ who says of Jerusalem, ‘She will be rebuilt,’ and of the temple, ‘Let its foundation be laid.’”

1.text: This is what the LORD says to Cyrus His anointed, whose right hand I have grasped to subdue nations before him, to disarm kings, to open the doors before him, so that the gates will not be shut:

2.text: “I will go before you and level the mountains; I will break down the gates of bronze and cut through the bars of iron.

3.text: I will give you the treasures of darkness and the riches hidden in secret places, so that you may know that I am the LORD, the God of Israel, who calls you by name.

4.text: For the sake of Jacob My servant and Israel My chosen one, I call you by name; I have given you a title of honor, though you have not known Me.

5.text: I am the LORD, and there is no other; there is no God but Me. I will equip you for battle, though you have not known Me,

6.text: so that all may know, from where the sun rises to where it sets, that there is none but Me; I am the LORD, and there is no other.

7.text: I form the light and create the darkness; I bring prosperity and create calamity. I, the LORD, do all these things.

8.text: Drip down, O heavens, from above, and let the skies pour down righteousness. Let the earth open up that salvation may sprout and righteousness spring up with it; I, the LORD, have created it.

9.text: Woe to him who quarrels with his Maker—one clay pot among many. Does the clay ask the potter, ‘What are you making?’ Does your work say, ‘He has no hands’?

10.text: Woe to him who says to his father, ‘What have you begotten?’ or to his mother, ‘What have you brought forth?’”

11.text: Thus says the LORD, the Holy One of Israel, and its Maker: “Concerning things to come, do you question Me about My sons, or instruct Me in the work of My hands?

12.text: It is I who made the earth and created man upon it. It was My hands that stretched out the heavens, and I ordained all their host.

13.text: I will raise up Cyrus in righteousness, and I will make all his ways straight. He will rebuild My city and set My exiles free, but not for payment or reward, says the LORD of Hosts.”

14.text: This is what the LORD says: “The products of Egypt and the merchandise of Cush, along with the Sabeans, men of stature, will come over to you and will be yours; they will trudge behind you; they will come over in chains and bow down to you. They will confess to you: ‘God is indeed with you, and there is no other; there is no other God.’”

15.text: Truly You are a God who hides Himself, O God of Israel, the Savior.

16.text: They will all be put to shame and humiliated; the makers of idols will depart together in disgrace.

17.text: But Israel will be saved by the LORD with an everlasting salvation; you will not be put to shame or humiliated, to ages everlasting.

18.text: For thus says the LORD, who created the heavens—He is God; He formed the earth and fashioned it; He established it; He did not create it to be empty, but formed it to be inhabited: “I am the LORD, and there is no other.

19.text: I have not spoken in secret, from a place in a land of darkness. I did not say to the descendants of Jacob, ‘Seek Me in a wasteland.’ I, the LORD, speak the truth; I say what is right.

20.text: Come, gather together, and draw near, you fugitives from the nations. Ignorant are those who carry idols of wood and pray to a god that cannot save.

21.text: Speak up and present your case—yes, let them take counsel together. Who foretold this long ago? Who announced it from ancient times? Was it not I, the LORD? There is no other God but Me, a righteous God and Savior; there is none but Me.

22.text: Turn to Me and be saved, all the ends of the earth; for I am God, and there is no other.

23.text: By Myself I have sworn; truth has gone out from My mouth, a word that will not be revoked: Every knee will bow before Me, every tongue will swear allegiance.

24.text: Surely they will say of Me, ‘In the LORD alone are righteousness and strength.’” All who rage against Him will come to Him and be put to shame.

25.text: In the LORD all descendants of Israel will be justified and will exult.

1.text: Bel crouches; Nebo cowers. Their idols weigh down beasts and cattle. The images you carry are burdensome, a load to the weary animal.

2.text: The gods cower; they crouch together, unable to relieve the burden; but they themselves go into captivity.

3.text: “Listen to Me, O house of Jacob, all the remnant of the house of Israel, who have been sustained from the womb, carried along since birth.

4.text: Even to your old age, I will be the same, and I will bear you up when you turn gray. I have made you, and I will carry you; I will sustain you and deliver you.

5.text: To whom will you liken Me or count Me equal? To whom will you compare Me, that we should be alike?

6.text: They pour out their bags of gold and weigh out silver on scales; they hire a goldsmith to fashion it into a god, so they can bow down and worship.

7.text: They lift it to their shoulder and carry it along; they set it in its place, and there it stands, not budging from that spot. They cry out to it, but it does not answer; it saves no one from his troubles.

8.text: Remember this and be brave; take it to heart, you transgressors!

9.text: Remember what happened long ago, for I am God, and there is no other; I am God, and there is none like Me.

10.text: I declare the end from the beginning, and from ancient times what is still to come. I say, ‘My purpose will stand, and all My good pleasure I will accomplish.’

11.text: I summon a bird of prey from the east, a man for My purpose from a far-off land. Truly I have spoken, and truly I will bring it to pass. I have planned it, and I will surely do it.

12.text: Listen to Me, you stubborn people, far removed from righteousness:

13.text: I am bringing My righteousness near; it is not far away, and My salvation will not be delayed. I will grant salvation to Zion and adorn Israel with My splendor.

1.text: “Go down and sit in the dust, O Virgin Daughter of Babylon. Sit on the ground without a throne, O Daughter of the Chaldeans! For you will no longer be called tender or delicate.

2.text: Take millstones and grind flour; remove your veil; strip off your skirt, bare your thigh, and wade through the streams.

3.text: Your nakedness will be uncovered and your shame will be exposed. I will take vengeance; I will spare no one.”

4.text: Our Redeemer—the LORD of Hosts is His name—is the Holy One of Israel.

5.text: “Sit in silence and go into darkness, O Daughter of the Chaldeans. For you will no longer be called the queen of kingdoms.

6.text: I was angry with My people; I profaned My heritage, and I placed them under your control. You showed them no mercy; even on the elderly you laid a most heavy yoke.

7.text: You said, ‘I will be queen forever.’ You did not take these things to heart or consider their outcome.

8.text: So now hear this, O lover of luxury who sits securely, who says to herself, ‘I am, and there is none besides me. I will never be a widow or know the loss of children.’

9.text: These two things will overtake you in a moment, in a single day: loss of children, and widowhood. They will come upon you in full measure, in spite of your many sorceries and the potency of your spells.

10.text: You were secure in your wickedness; you said, ‘No one sees me.’ Your wisdom and knowledge led you astray; you told yourself, ‘I am, and there is none besides me.’

11.text: But disaster will come upon you; you will not know how to charm it away. A calamity will befall you that you will be unable to ward off. Devastation will happen to you suddenly and unexpectedly.

12.text: So take your stand with your spells and with your many sorceries, with which you have wearied yourself from your youth. Perhaps you will succeed; perhaps you will inspire terror!

13.text: You are wearied by your many counselors; let them come forward now and save you—your astrologers who observe the stars, who monthly predict your fate.

14.text: Surely they are like stubble; the fire will burn them up. They cannot deliver themselves from the power of the flame. There will be no coals to warm them or fire to sit beside.

15.text: This is what they are to you—those with whom you have labored and traded from youth—each one strays in his own direction; not one of them can save you.

1.text: “Listen to this, O house of Jacob, you who are called by the name of Israel, who have descended from the line of Judah, who swear by the name of the LORD, who invoke the God of Israel—but not in truth or righteousness—

2.text: who indeed call yourselves after the holy city and lean on the God of Israel; the LORD of Hosts is His name.

3.text: I foretold the former things long ago; they came out of My mouth and I proclaimed them. Suddenly I acted, and they came to pass.

4.text: For I knew that you are stubborn; your neck is iron and your forehead is bronze.

5.text: Therefore I declared it to you long ago; I announced it before it came to pass, so that you could not claim, ‘My idol has done this; my carved image and molten god has ordained it.’

6.text: You have heard these things; look at them all. Will you not acknowledge them? From now on I will tell you of new things, hidden things unknown to you.

7.text: They are created now, and not long ago; you have not heard of them before today. So you cannot claim, ‘I already knew them!’

8.text: You have never heard; you have never understood; for a long time your ears have not been open. For I knew how deceitful you are; you have been called a rebel from birth.

9.text: For the sake of My name I will delay My wrath; for the sake of My praise I will restrain it, so that you will not be cut off.

10.text: See, I have refined you, but not as silver; I have tested you in the furnace of affliction.

11.text: For My own sake, My very own sake, I will act; for how can I let Myself be defamed? I will not yield My glory to another.

12.text: Listen to Me, O Jacob, and Israel, whom I have called: I am He; I am the first, and I am the last.

13.text: Surely My own hand founded the earth, and My right hand spread out the heavens; when I summon them, they stand up together.

14.text: Come together, all of you, and listen: Which of the idols has foretold these things? The LORD’s chosen ally will carry out His desire against Babylon, and His arm will be against the Chaldeans.

15.text: I, even I, have spoken; yes, I have called him. I have brought him, and he will succeed in his mission.

16.text: Come near to Me and listen to this: From the beginning I have not spoken in secret; from the time it happened, I was there.” And now the Lord GOD has sent me, accompanied by His Spirit.

17.text: Thus says the LORD your Redeemer, the Holy One of Israel: “I am the LORD your God, who teaches you for your benefit, who directs you in the way you should go.

18.text: If only you had paid attention to My commandments, your peace would have been like a river, and your righteousness like waves of the sea.

19.text: Your descendants would have been as countless as the sand, and your offspring as numerous as its grains; their name would never be cut off or eliminated from My presence.”

20.text: Leave Babylon! Flee from the Chaldeans! Declare it with a shout of joy, proclaim it, let it go out to the ends of the earth, saying, “The LORD has redeemed His servant Jacob!”

21.text: They did not thirst when He led them through the deserts; He made water flow for them from the rock; He split the rock, and water gushed out.

22.text: “There is no peace,” says the LORD, “for the wicked.”

1.text: Listen to Me, O islands; pay attention, O distant peoples: The LORD called Me from the womb; from the body of My mother He named Me.

2.text: He made My mouth like a sharp sword; He hid Me in the shadow of His hand. He made Me like a polished arrow; He hid Me in His quiver.

3.text: He said to Me, “You are My Servant, Israel, in whom I will display My glory.”

4.text: But I said, “I have labored in vain, I have spent My strength in futility and vanity; yet My vindication is with the LORD, and My reward is with My God.”

5.text: And now says the LORD, who formed Me from the womb to be His Servant, to bring Jacob back to Him, that Israel might be gathered to Him—for I am honored in the sight of the LORD, and My God is My strength—

6.text: He says: “It is not enough for You to be My Servant, to raise up the tribes of Jacob, and to restore the protected ones of Israel. I will also make You a light for the nations, to bring My salvation to the ends of the earth.”

7.text: Thus says the LORD, the Redeemer and Holy One of Israel, to Him who was despised and abhorred by the nation, to the Servant of rulers: “Kings will see You and rise, and princes will bow down, because of the LORD, who is faithful, the Holy One of Israel, who has chosen You.”

8.text: This is what the LORD says: “In the time of favor I will answer You, and in the day of salvation I will help You; I will keep You and appoint You to be a covenant for the people, to restore the land, to apportion its desolate inheritances,

9.text: to say to the prisoners, ‘Come out,’ and to those in darkness, ‘Show yourselves.’ They will feed along the pathways, and find pasture on every barren hill.

10.text: They will not hunger or thirst, nor will scorching heat or sun beat down on them. For He who has compassion on them will guide them and lead them beside springs of water.

11.text: I will turn all My mountains into roads, and My highways will be raised up.

12.text: Behold, they will come from far away, from the north and from the west, and from the land of Aswan.”

13.text: Shout for joy, O heavens; rejoice, O earth; break forth in song, O mountains! For the LORD has comforted His people, and He will have compassion on His afflicted ones.

14.text: But Zion said, “The LORD has forsaken me; the Lord has forgotten me!”

15.text: “Can a woman forget her nursing child, or lack compassion for the son of her womb? Even if she could forget, I will not forget you!

16.text: Behold, I have inscribed you on the palms of My hands; your walls are ever before Me.

17.text: Your builders hasten back; your destroyers and wreckers depart from you.

18.text: Lift up your eyes and look around. They all gather together; they come to you. As surely as I live,” declares the LORD, “you will wear them all as jewelry and put them on like a bride.

19.text: For your ruined and desolate places and your ravaged land will now indeed be too small for your people, and those who devoured you will be far away.

20.text: Yet the children of your bereavement will say in your hearing, ‘This place is too small for us; make room for us to live here.’

21.text: Then you will say in your heart, ‘Who has begotten these for me? I was bereaved and barren; I was exiled and rejected. So who has reared them? Look, I was left all alone, so where did they come from?’”

22.text: This is what the Lord GOD says: “Behold, I will lift up My hand to the nations, and raise My banner to the peoples. They will bring your sons in their arms and carry your daughters on their shoulders.

23.text: Kings will be your foster fathers, and their queens your nursing mothers. They will bow to you facedown and lick the dust at your feet. Then you will know that I am the LORD; those who hope in Me will never be put to shame.”

24.text: Can the plunder be snatched from the mighty, or the captives of a tyrant be delivered?

25.text: Indeed, this is what the LORD says: “Even the captives of the mighty will be taken away, and the plunder of the tyrant will be retrieved; I will contend with those who contend with you, and I will save your children.

26.text: I will make your oppressors eat their own flesh; they will be drunk on their own blood, as with wine. Then all mankind will know that I, the LORD, am your Savior and your Redeemer, the Mighty One of Jacob.”

1.text: This is what the LORD says: “Where is your mother’s certificate of divorce with which I sent her away? Or to which of My creditors did I sell you? Look, you were sold for your iniquities, and for your transgressions your mother was sent away.

2.text: Why was no one there when I arrived? Why did no one answer when I called? Is My hand too short to redeem you? Or do I lack the strength to deliver you? Behold, My rebuke dries up the sea; I turn the rivers into a desert; the fish rot for lack of water and die of thirst.

3.text: I clothe the heavens in black and make sackcloth their covering.”

4.text: The Lord GOD has given Me the tongue of discipleship, to sustain the weary with a word. He awakens Me morning by morning; He awakens My ear to listen as a disciple.

5.text: The Lord GOD has opened My ears, and I have not been rebellious, nor have I turned back.

6.text: I offered My back to those who struck Me, and My cheeks to those who tore out My beard. I did not hide My face from scorn and spittle.

7.text: Because the Lord GOD helps Me, I have not been disgraced; therefore I have set My face like flint, and I know that I will not be put to shame.

8.text: The One who vindicates Me is near. Who will dare to contend with Me? Let us confront each other! Who has a case against Me? Let him approach Me!

9.text: Surely the Lord GOD helps Me. Who is there to condemn Me? See, they will all wear out like a garment; the moths will devour them.

10.text: Who among you fears the LORD and obeys the voice of His Servant? Who among you walks in darkness and has no light? Let him trust in the name of the LORD; let him lean on his God.

11.text: Behold, all you who kindle a fire, who array yourselves with firebrands, walk in the light of your fire and of the firebrands you have lit! This is what you will receive from My hand: You will lie down in a place of torment.

1.text: “Listen to Me, you who pursue righteousness, you who seek the LORD: Look to the rock from which you were cut, and to the quarry from which you were hewn.

2.text: Look to Abraham your father, and to Sarah who gave you birth. When I called him, he was but one; then I blessed him and multiplied him.

3.text: For the LORD will comfort Zion and will look with compassion on all her ruins; He will make her wilderness like Eden and her desert like the garden of the LORD. Joy and gladness will be found in her, thanksgiving and melodious song.

4.text: Pay attention to Me, My people, and listen to Me, My nation; for a law will go out from Me, and My justice will become a light to the nations; I will bring it about quickly.

5.text: My righteousness draws near, My salvation is on the way, and My arms will bring justice to the nations. The islands will look for Me and wait in hope for My arm.

6.text: Lift up your eyes to the heavens, and look at the earth below; for the heavens will vanish like smoke, the earth will wear out like a garment, and its people will die like gnats. But My salvation will last forever, and My righteousness will never fail.

7.text: Listen to Me, you who know what is right, you people with My law in your hearts: Do not fear the scorn of men; do not be broken by their insults.

8.text: For the moth will devour them like a garment, and the worm will eat them like wool. But My righteousness will last forever, My salvation through all generations.”

9.text: Awake, awake, put on strength, O arm of the LORD. Wake up as in days past, as in generations of old. Was it not You who cut Rahab to pieces, who pierced through the dragon?

10.text: Was it not You who dried up the sea, the waters of the great deep, who made a road in the depths of the sea for the redeemed to cross over?

11.text: So the redeemed of the LORD will return and enter Zion with singing, crowned with everlasting joy. Gladness and joy will overtake them, and sorrow and sighing will flee.

12.text: “I, even I, am He who comforts you. Why should you be afraid of mortal man, of a son of man who withers like grass?

13.text: But you have forgotten the LORD, your Maker, who stretched out the heavens and laid the foundations of the earth. You live in terror all day long because of the fury of the oppressor who is bent on destruction. But where is the fury of the oppressor?

14.text: The captive will soon be freed; he will not die in the dungeon, and his bread will not be lacking.

15.text: For I am the LORD your God who stirs up the sea so that its waves roar—the LORD of Hosts is His name.

16.text: I have put My words in your mouth, and covered you with the shadow of My hand, to establish the heavens, to found the earth, and to say to Zion, ‘You are My people.’”

17.text: Awake, awake! Rise up, O Jerusalem, you who have drunk from the hand of the LORD the cup of His fury; you who have drained the goblet to the dregs—the cup that makes men stagger.

18.text: Among all the sons she bore, there is no one to guide her; among all the sons she brought up, there is no one to take her hand.

19.text: These pairs have befallen you: devastation and destruction, famine and sword. Who will grieve for you? Who can comfort you?

20.text: Your sons have fainted; they lie at the head of every street, like an antelope in a net. They are full of the wrath of the LORD, the rebuke of your God.

21.text: Therefore now hear this, you afflicted one, drunken, but not with wine.

22.text: Thus says your Lord, the LORD, even your God, who defends His people: “See, I have removed from your hand the cup of staggering. From that goblet, the cup of My fury, you will never drink again.

23.text: I will place it in the hands of your tormentors, who told you: ‘Lie down, so we can walk over you,’ so that you made your back like the ground, like a street to be traversed.”

1.text: Awake, awake, clothe yourself with strength, O Zion! Put on your garments of splendor, O Jerusalem, holy city! For the uncircumcised and unclean will no longer enter you.

2.text: Shake off your dust! Rise up and sit on your throne, O Jerusalem. Remove the chains from your neck, O captive Daughter of Zion.

3.text: For this is what the LORD says: “You were sold for nothing, and without money you will be redeemed.”

4.text: For this is what the Lord GOD says: “At first My people went down to Egypt to live, then Assyria oppressed them without cause.

5.text: And now what have I here? declares the LORD. For My people have been taken without cause; those who rule them taunt, declares the LORD, and My name is blasphemed continually all day long.

6.text: Therefore My people will know My name; therefore they will know on that day that I am He who speaks. Here I am!”

7.text: How beautiful on the mountains are the feet of those who bring good news, who proclaim peace, who bring good tidings, who proclaim salvation, who say to Zion, “Your God reigns!”

8.text: Listen! Your watchmen lift up their voices, together they shout for joy. For every eye will see when the LORD returns to Zion.

9.text: Break forth in joy, sing together, O ruins of Jerusalem, for the LORD has comforted His people; He has redeemed Jerusalem.

10.text: The LORD has bared His holy arm in the sight of all the nations; all the ends of the earth will see the salvation of our God.

11.text: Depart, depart, go out from there! Touch no unclean thing; come out from it, purify yourselves, you who carry the vessels of the LORD.

12.text: For you will not leave in a hurry nor flee in haste, for the LORD goes before you, and the God of Israel is your rear guard.

13.text: Behold, My Servant will prosper; He will be raised and lifted up and highly exalted.

14.text: Just as many were appalled at Him—His appearance was disfigured beyond that of any man, and His form was marred beyond human likeness—

15.text: so He will sprinkle many nations. Kings will shut their mouths because of Him. For they will see what they have not been told, and they will understand what they have not heard.

1.text: Who has believed our message? And to whom has the arm of the LORD been revealed?

2.text: He grew up before Him like a tender shoot, and like a root out of dry ground. He had no stately form or majesty to attract us, no beauty that we should desire Him.

3.text: He was despised and rejected by men, a man of sorrows, acquainted with grief. Like one from whom men hide their faces, He was despised, and we esteemed Him not.

4.text: Surely He took up our infirmities and carried our sorrows; yet we considered Him stricken, struck down by God, and afflicted.

5.text: But He was pierced for our transgressions, He was crushed for our iniquities; the punishment that brought us peace was upon Him, and by His stripes we are healed.

6.text: We all like sheep have gone astray, each one has turned to his own way; and the LORD has laid upon Him the iniquity of us all.

7.text: He was oppressed and afflicted, yet He did not open His mouth. He was led like a lamb to the slaughter, and as a sheep before her shearers is silent, so He did not open His mouth.

8.text: By oppression and judgment He was taken away, and who can recount His descendants? For He was cut off from the land of the living; He was stricken for the transgression of My people.

9.text: He was assigned a grave with the wicked, and with a rich man in His death, although He had done no violence, nor was any deceit in His mouth.

10.text: Yet it was the LORD’s will to crush Him and to cause Him to suffer; and when His soul is made a guilt offering, He will see His offspring, He will prolong His days, and the good pleasure of the LORD will prosper in His hand.

11.text: After the anguish of His soul, He will see the light of life and be satisfied. By His knowledge My righteous Servant will justify many, and He will bear their iniquities.

12.text: Therefore I will allot Him a portion with the great, and He will divide the spoils with the strong, because He has poured out His life unto death, and He was numbered with the transgressors. Yet He bore the sin of many and made intercession for the transgressors.

1.text: “Shout for joy, O barren woman, who bears no children; break forth in song and cry aloud, you who have never travailed; because more are the children of the desolate woman than of her who has a husband,” says the LORD.

2.text: “Enlarge the site of your tent, stretch out the curtains of your dwellings, do not hold back. Lengthen your ropes and drive your stakes in deep.

3.text: For you will spread out to the right and left; your descendants will dispossess the nations and inhabit the desolate cities.

4.text: Do not be afraid, for you will not be put to shame; do not be intimidated, for you will not be humiliated. For you will forget the shame of your youth and will remember no more the reproach of your widowhood.

5.text: For your husband is your Maker—the LORD of Hosts is His name—the Holy One of Israel is your Redeemer; He is called the God of all the earth.

6.text: For the LORD has called you back, like a wife deserted and wounded in spirit, like the rejected wife of one’s youth,” says your God.

7.text: “For a brief moment I forsook you, but with great compassion I will bring you back.

8.text: In a surge of anger I hid My face from you for a moment, but with everlasting kindness I will have compassion on you,” says the LORD your Redeemer.

9.text: “For to Me this is like the days of Noah, when I swore that the waters of Noah would never again cover the earth. So I have sworn that I will not be angry with you or rebuke you.

10.text: Though the mountains may be removed and the hills may be shaken, My loving devotion will not depart from you, and My covenant of peace will not be broken,” says the LORD, who has compassion on you.

11.text: “O afflicted city, lashed by storms, without solace, surely I will set your stones in antimony and lay your foundations with sapphires.

12.text: I will make your pinnacles of rubies, your gates of sparkling jewels, and all your walls of precious stones.

13.text: Then all your sons will be taught by the LORD, and great will be their prosperity.

14.text: In righteousness you will be established, far from oppression, for you will have no fear. Terror will be far removed, for it will not come near you.

15.text: If anyone attacks you, it is not from Me; whoever assails you will fall before you.

16.text: Behold, I have created the craftsman who fans the coals into flame and forges a weapon fit for its task; and I have created the destroyer to wreak havoc.

17.text: No weapon formed against you shall prosper, and you will refute every tongue that accuses you. This is the heritage of the servants of the LORD, and their vindication is from Me,” declares the LORD.

1.text: “Come, all you who are thirsty, come to the waters; and you without money, come, buy, and eat! Come, buy wine and milk without money and without cost!

2.text: Why spend money on that which is not bread, and your labor on that which does not satisfy? Listen carefully to Me, and eat what is good, and your soul will delight in the richest of foods.

3.text: Incline your ear and come to Me; listen, so that your soul may live. I will make with you an everlasting covenant—My loving devotion promised to David.

4.text: Behold, I have made him a witness to the nations, a leader and commander of the peoples.

5.text: Surely you will summon a nation you do not know, and nations who do not know you will run to you. For the LORD your God, the Holy One of Israel, has bestowed glory on you.”

6.text: Seek the LORD while He may be found; call on Him while He is near.

7.text: Let the wicked man forsake his way and the unrighteous man his thoughts; let him return to the LORD, that He may have compassion, and to our God, for He will freely pardon.

8.text: “For My thoughts are not your thoughts, neither are your ways My ways,” declares the LORD.

9.text: “For as the heavens are higher than the earth, so My ways are higher than your ways and My thoughts than your thoughts.

10.text: For just as rain and snow fall from heaven and do not return without watering the earth, making it bud and sprout, and providing seed to sow and food to eat,

11.text: so My word that proceeds from My mouth will not return to Me empty, but it will accomplish what I please, and it will prosper where I send it.

12.text: You will indeed go out with joy and be led forth in peace; the mountains and hills will burst into song before you, and all the trees of the field will clap their hands.

13.text: Instead of the thornbush, the cypress will grow, and instead of the brier, the myrtle will spring up; this will make a name for the LORD, an everlasting sign, never to be destroyed.”
